# Title

**Descriptive Measures**\
*How can we summarize a messy dataset so it tells a clear story?*

<br>

------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Why summarize?

![A messy scatter of points representing raw observations](images/messy_points.png){fig-alt="Scatter of unstructured data emphasizing need for summarization" width="80%"}

**Prompt:** *If you had 370 observations, what would you report first?*\
(Expect: size, center, spread, shape, and key relationships.)

------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Scales of measurement

**Nominal · Ordinal · Interval · Ratio**

-   **Nominal:** labels/categories; no order.\
-   **Ordinal:** order, but uneven gaps.\
-   **Interval:** equal gaps; no true zero (e.g., °C).\
-   **Ratio:** equal gaps; true zero (e.g., time, length).

::: callout-tip
## Quick check

Which statistics are meaningful at each scale?\
- Mean & SD require **interval/ratio**.\
- Median & percentiles work for **ordinal+**.
:::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## SUM: when it makes sense (and when it doesn’t)

::: columns
::: column{width="50%"}

### ✅ SUM is meaningful when…
- the variable is **additive**
- units are “total-able” (minutes, dollars, people)
- **0** means “none”

<div style="height:0.7rem;"></div>

**Examples**
- total minutes delayed  
- total injuries  
- number of severity-3 accidents (sum of 1/0)

::: column
::: column{width="50%"}

### ❌ SUM is nonsense when…
- it’s an **ID** or label
- it’s **ordinal** (1–4) not numeric magnitude
- it’s already an **average/rate**

<div style="height:0.7rem;"></div>

**Examples**
- sum of accident IDs ❌  
- sum of severity codes ❌  
- sum of “average speed” ❌ (unless weighted)

::: column
::: columns

---

**Fast test:** *Can you add two rows together and keep the same meaning + units?*


## IQR: the middle 50% of the data

<div style="font-size:1.1rem; opacity:.75;">
IQR = P75 − P25  
It measures **the width of the middle half** of the distribution.
</div>

<div style="height:.7rem;"></div>

<div class="callout callout-style-simple callout-note" style="font-size:1rem;">
When distributions are skewed or have outliers, **IQR is more stable than SD**.
</div>

<div style="height:.5rem;"></div>

<div style="font-size:1rem;">
- **P25 (Q1):** 25% of scores fall below this  
- **P75 (Q3):** 75% fall below this  
- The shaded region between Q1 and Q3 is the **IQR band**
</div>

**n** = number of usable observations in your sample.\
**N** = size of the full population (often unknown).

::: callout-tip collapse="true" \## In Excel `=COUNT(A2:A371)` :::

::: callout-tip collapse="true" \## In R

``` r
length(x)       # or dplyr::count() for data frames
```

:::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Central tendency

We have **three** common flavors—each answers a *different* question.

-   **Mean**: balancing point; sensitive to outliers.\
-   **Median**: middle value; robust to skew/outliers.\
-   **Mode**: most frequent value; useful for categorical data.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## Mean (center as balance)

![Dots on a number line balanced on a fulcrum at the mean](images/mean_balance.png){fig-alt="Number line with data points balanced at the mean" width="80%"}

**Interpretation:** *If each point had weight 1, the plank balances here.*

::: callout-tip collapse="true" \## Excel & R **Excel:** `=AVERAGE(A2:A371)`\
**R:** `mean(x, na.rm = TRUE)` :::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## Median (center as position)

![Sorted values with the middle one highlighted](images/median_sorted.png){fig-alt="Sorted values with the median highlighted" width="80%"}

**Why it matters:** robust when distributions are skewed (e.g., incomes).

::: callout-tip collapse="true" \## Excel & R **Excel:** `=MEDIAN(A2:A371)`\
**R:** `median(x, na.rm = TRUE)` :::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## Mode (most common)

![Bars with one clearly taller category](images/mode_bar.png){fig-alt="Bar chart with one dominant bar illustrating the mode" width="70%"}

**Note:** there may be multiple modes or none (flat distribution).

::: callout-tip collapse="true" \## Excel & R **Excel:** `=MODE.SNGL(A2:A371)`\
**R:** `names(which.max(table(x)))` :::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Variation (how spread out?)

-   **Variance (s\^2 or σ\^2):** average squared distance from the mean.\
-   **Standard deviation (s or σ):** typical distance in original units.

![Bell curve with bands at 1 SD and 2 SD](images/sd_bands.png){fig-alt="Distribution with standard deviation bands" width="70%"}

::: callout-tip collapse="true" \## Excel & R **Excel:** `=STDEV.S(A2:A371)` (sample) · `=STDEV.P(...)` (population)\
**R:** `sd(x, na.rm = TRUE)`\
:::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Percentiles & quartiles

![Cumulative distribution with Q1, Median (Q2), Q3 marked](images/quartiles_cdf.png){fig-alt="Cumulative distribution showing Q1, Q2, Q3" width="75%"}

**Interpretation:** the *p*th percentile is the value with *p*% of data at or below it.

::: callout-tip collapse="true" \## Excel & R **Excel:** `=QUARTILE.INC(A2:A371, 1|2|3)` · `=PERCENTILE.INC(range, p)`\
**R:** `quantile(x, probs = c(.25,.5,.75), type = 7, na.rm = TRUE)` :::

::: callout-note

# IQR & outliers (boxplot view)

![Boxplot with box (Q1–Q3), median line, whiskers, and outliers as points](images/boxplot_iqr.png){fig-alt="Boxplot illustrating quartiles, whiskers, and outliers" width="70%"}

**IQR = Q3 − Q1**; outliers often flagged at **Q1 − 1.5·IQR** or **Q3 + 1.5·IQR**.

::: callout-tip collapse="true" \## Excel & R **Excel:** `=QUARTILE.INC(...)` then compute IQR.\
**R:** `IQR(x, na.rm = TRUE)` :::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Two-way tables (categorical × categorical)

**Start with counts; then layer in percentages.**

1.  Cross‑tab of **Genre × Rating** (raw counts).\
2.  Add **marginal totals**.\
3.  Compute **row %** (conditional on row).\
4.  Compute **column %** (conditional on column).\
5.  Finally, **table %** for overall share.

::: callout-tip collapse="true" \## Excel & R **Excel:** Insert → PivotTable → Values (Count), add Row/Column fields; show values as % of row/column.\
**R:** `dplyr::count(genre, rating) |> tidyr::pivot_wider()` then `prop.table()` by margin. :::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## What can go wrong?

-   **Confusing similar-sounding percentages**:
    -   \% of movies that are Drama **and** Rated R = 72/370\
    -   \% of Dramas that are Rated R = 72/119\
    -   \% of movies that are Dramas = 119/370

**Takeaway:** always state the **denominator**.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Relatedness: covariance & correlation

![Scatterplots from strong negative to strong positive correlation](images/correlation_grid.png){fig-alt="Grid of scatterplots showing correlation values from -1 to +1" width="80%"}

-   **Covariance:** direction + scale‑dependent magnitude.\
-   **Correlation (r):** standardized to \[−1, 1\]; strength of *linear* pattern.

::: callout-caution
**Correlation ≠ Causation.**\
Check for confounders, nonlinearity, and outliers.
:::

::: callout-tip collapse="true" \## Excel & R **Excel:** `=CORREL(A2:A371, B2:B371)`\
**R:** `cor(x, y, use = "complete.obs")` :::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Wrap‑up

**Report the story with four anchors:**\
**size (n)** · **center (mean/median)** · **spread (SD/IQR)** · **relationships (tables/r)**.

**Exit prompt:** *Pick one dataset you care about. Which two descriptive measures would you lead with—and why?*
